titleproper.value:
Guide to the Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting (FAIR) Records
                    <num>TAM.282</num>

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2012-03-29T19:16-0400</date>

unittitle.value: Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting (FAIR) Records

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value:
Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting (FAIR) is a progressive media watch organization founded in 1986 by journalist Jeff Cohen. FAIR publishes 
                <title render="italic">Extra!</title>a magazine of media criticism and produces 
                <title render="italic">Counterspin</title>, a radio news program. It is active against censorship, advocates diversity, and the break up of the dominant media conglomerates. The collection includes: correspondence (mostly that of Jeff Cohen), internal documents, and back issues of publications.

p.value:
Published citations should take the following form: 
                <lb/>
                <lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; 
                <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives 
                <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library 
                <lb/>70 Washington Square South 
                <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting (FAIR), a progressive media watch organization that works with journalists and activists, was founded in 1986 by journalist Jeff Cohen. FAIR publishes 
                <title render="italic">Extra!</title>a magazine of media criticism, produces 
                <title render="italic">Counterspin</title>, a radio news program, conducts media research and produces reports (notably through its Womens' Desk and Racism Watch Desk units), opposes censorship, advocates for greater diversity and representation of minority viewpoints, and believes that structural reform is ultimately needed to break up the dominant media conglomerates, establish independent public broadcasting and promote strong non-profit sources of information. For more information, see the FAIR website www.fair.org.

Arranged alphabetically, this collection contains correspondence (mostly that of Jeff Cohen), internal documents, reports and studies, editorial material pertaining to Extra!, back issues (1992) of 
                <title render="italic">Counterspin: A Memo on Campaign Coverage from FAIR</title>, published and unpublished writings by Jeff Cohen and others, a file on FAIR's Los Angeles chapter, and another on related organizations.
